abstracts.cdata!:
The overall assessment of the project is
            rated as satisfactory. The main lessons drawn for the future
            operations in the road sector include: 1) Nigeria is blessed
            with numerous experienced highly capable road contractors
            and engineering consultants. Through the strict application
            of the Bank's procurement procedures, unqualified firms
            can be weeded out. 2) Through adequate incentives, including
            the provision of training, motivated project management
            units can be created to execute projects. 3) The current
            set-up for the management and financing of roads in Nigeria
            is not viable. Any future engagement of the Bank in the road
            sector in Nigeria should only be considered after the
            successful implementation of the reforms proposed under the
            Road Vision 2000 Initiative. 4) After the enactment of the
            National Roads Board Fund Decree, the Bank should assist
            preparatory activities for the implementation of the reform.
            Thereafter, an adaptable program lending might be the right
            tool to carefully reengage the Bank and to expand the
            Bank's possible involvement based on clearly defined
            and agreed upon benchmarks. 5) Possible Bank/International
            Development Association financing could cover initial
            years' peak demand of a road recovery program,
            provision of guarantees for private sector road management
            concessions, and funding for the rehabilitation of the badly
            deteriorated rural road network.
